She leans in, hands me

Actual meaning, though,

And no, my world doesn't implode,

386.text:
and, as a result of that, over the years,

391.text:
with what causes worry
versus peace of mind.

396.text: And I noticed a very interesting pattern,

400.text:
a pattern that helped me
uncover the culprit

404.text:
that leads to most of what we worry about
and that robs us of our peace of mind,

412.text: What you tolerate you worry about.

417.text: What you tolerate you worry about.

424.text:
what you are tolerating right now
you are worrying about.

431.text:
Meaning, when you say "yes"
and you really want to say "no" -

437.text:
you know those moments
where all you want to do is say no,

444.text:
and what you tolerate will always,
sooner or later, drive you to worry.

452.text:
Now, would it surprise you to know
that 95% of North Americans

456.text:
either go to bed or wake up
worrying about something every single day?

462.text:
We, ladies and gentlemen, are a bunch
of professional "worryaholics."

467.text:
In fact, we worry so much nowadays
that the phrase "I'm thinking about this"

473.text:
has now culturally been replaced
by "I'm worrying about this."

488.text:
That, my friends, is like putting a 40%
down payment on a house you'll never own.

494.text: How ridiculous would that be, right?

498.text:
on a house you'll never see,
smell, experience, or own.

503.text:
Yet, when it comes to worry,
we do it every day.

508.text:
Thirty percent of what
we worry about - get this -

516.text:
Has anyone ever 
accidentally hit "reply all" -

525.text:
on a massive rant email
that was meant for Bob's eyes only?

534.text:
Twelve percent of what we worry about
are needless worries about our health.

538.text:
For example, you got a headache
for three days in a row, and, boom!

543.text: You are worried about a brain tumor.

546.text:
Oh, and if you have the brilliance
of consulting with "Dr. Google,"

551.text:
now you go from having a brain tumor
to having six months left to live, right?

558.text:
Ten percent of what we worry about
are petty miscellaneous worries,

565.text: like what to cook for dinner,

567.text:
or what shoes to wear
for a TED Talk, for example.

572.text:
Now, I don't know
if you're calculating this,

574.text:
but that leaves 8%
for real, legitimate worries,

581.text:
which means that 92% of what we're
worrying about is complete nonsense,

587.text: and that nonsense, by the way,

590.text:
not only keeps us
from being at out best - oh, no -

594.text: it keeps us from actually living.

598.text:
So, what if, what if
we took all this energy

602.text: that we use to worry about this crazy 92%,

606.text: and what if we repurposed it?

609.text:
What if we repurposed it
to do something good,

620.text:
Well, as a very proud
recovering worryaholic myself,

625.text:
and a strong believer

627.text:
to increase what I call
our units of happiness,

637.text:
to help me basically

641.text:
and quickly snap me out

643.text: that I find myself in on a regular basis -

647.text:
and, if I'm to be transparent

651.text:
absolutely every day,
including this very moment.

655.text: And I call this my "HERO" formula.

664.text:
First, you've got to hush the noise
and hush the chatter,

670.text:
so that you can reconnect
with what you truly want.

674.text: What do you wholeheartedly believe in?

679.text:
What are you willing or not willing to do

685.text: "Yes, I want you to come for a visit.

704.text:

711.text: Because what you tolerate you worry about.

720.text:
Evaluate what and who

726.text:

732.text:
How many of those are slowly

739.text:
and this will require

769.text:
what and who is causing

778.text: Because what you tolerate you worry about.

787.text:
Ritualize the habits that have
the potential to bring your best self,

801.text: What do they all have in common?

803.text:
Well, apart of course from being

806.text: like we know them to be,

808.text:
they all have a few simple daily rituals

815.text:
Not working past 3 o'clock
in the afternoon, for example.

Now that is a concept

because I'm about

828.text:

Now, keep in mind that not all rituals

846.text:

853.text:
and look at emails

of useless worry,

Successful people know

882.text:
of their daily habits

886.text:
They truly do know what they need

922.text:
what the heck are you tolerating

927.text: Because what you tolerate you worry about.

933.text:
Hush, evaluate, ritualize,
and finally my absolute favorite: "Own."

939.text:
See, it's not enough to know it,
you've got own it.

948.text:
Own the fact that you are responsible
for what you choose to worry about,

952.text: and that, as of today, right now,

955.text:
you will no longer tolerate the things,
the people, and the habits

959.text: that are causing you to worry.

962.text: Peace of mind is a choice.

965.text:
It's a choice that requires
a lot of commitment, I'll grant you that.

969.text:
It's also a choice that requires
a whole lot of guts and courage. Why?

975.text:
Because it's not easy to say "no"
to someone we love,

982.text:
No, it is not easy to go to the gym
day in and day out

986.text: after long, hard days at work, it's not,

991.text:
And it is certainly not easy
to treat ourselves

994.text: as importantly as we treat everyone else,

1002.text:
So, the next time you worry
about something,

1004.text:
first remember you've got a 92% chance
that what you're worrying about

1008.text: is a total waste of time and energy.

1012.text:
Second, apply the HERO formula -
hush, evaluate, ritualize, and own -

1018.text:
and ask yourself, "What am I tolerating?
Who am I putting up with?"

1024.text:
And, if all hell breaks loose
and you can't remember the HERO formula -

1030.text: here is my backup plan for you:

1033.text:
I want you to set yourself

1047.text:
And I actually think
it's absolutely brilliant.

1050.text: As she goes through the week,

1052.text:
and as worry hits her in the face,

1060.text: Would you be part of the 92%?

1066.text:
I will schedule you in
and I will worry about you on Friday,

when Friday comes, how many worries

1085.text:
Now, I was nine years old
when I embraced the HERO in me.

1102.text:
Recently, my mother had
a nice, little opportunity

1105.text: to reconnect with the HERO in her.

1108.text: We're sitting at the kitchen table,

1110.text:
having the most intense
and passionate conversation -

1114.text:
as always in my family,
there is no other kind;

1123.text:
As I go to pick up the phone,
I see my mother going,

1126.text: "Isabelle, je pas ici," I'm not here.

1132.text:
"Are you kidding me?
This is way too good to be true.

1135.text:
Who do I have to pay for this? Because
I feel like we've been here before."

1144.text:
I lean in, hand her the phone, and say,
like it's payback time,

1153.text: Don't be afraid to speak your truth.

1155.text:
If you can't say 'no' 
to what you don't want,

1157.text:
you will never have the time
and the energy for what you do want."

1172.text: So, my question for you is this:

1175.text:
If - and "if" being
the operative word here -

1179.text:
if you are worrying and tolerating
something or someone

1188.text:
or will you choose
